ought to.translation[0].definitions[0].d: used to say that someone should do something because it is the best or most sensible thing to do
ought to.translation[0].definitions[0].e: You really ought to quit smoking.
The company ought to be making changes in its marketing strategy.
What sort of crimes ought the police to concentrate on?
You were out enjoying yourself when you ought to have been studying.
ought to.translation[0].definitions[1].d: used to make a suggestion about something you think is a good idea, especially in a social situation
ought to.translation[0].definitions[1].e: We ought to get together some time soon.
You ought to meet him; he’s really nice.
We ought to get her some flowers for her birthday.
ought to.translation[0].definitions[2].d: used to say that someone should do something or something should happen, because it is morally right or fair
ought to.translation[0].definitions[2].e: You ought to be ashamed of yourself.
The courts ought to treat black and white defendants in exactly the same way.
Many people felt that America ought not to take part in the war.
ought to.translation[0].definitions[3].d: used to say that you think something will probably happen, is probably true etc
ought to.translation[0].definitions[3].e: He left two hours ago, so he ought to be there by now.
They ought to win – they’ve trained hard enough.
That ought to be enough potatoes for eight people.
New technology ought to make this easier.
ought to.translation[0].note_box[0].head: GRAMMAR: Patterns with ought to
ought to.translation[0].note_box[0].item: You say that someone ought to do something
You say that someone ought to have done something
You ought to have explained  (=but you did not)
You say that someone ought not to do something
You say that someone ought not to have done something
She ought not to have gone  (=but she did go)
You ask ought someone to do something
You ask ought someone to have done something
Ought we to have told them?
